repnme.cdata!:
Mauritania - Urban Infrastructure and Pilot
            Decentralization Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project is rated satisfacotry as it
            achieved most relevant objectives. The evaluation cites four
            major factors that make sustainability likely. The
            performances of both the World Bank and the Borrower are
            assessed as satisfactory overall. These are among the
            lessons learned: 1) The project has clearly demonstrated
            that the delegation of contract management and reliance on
            private consultants are powerful and successful means of
            leveraging the otherwise linited municipal capabilities. The
            partnership among the municipalities, the public works
            executing agency of Mauritania (AMEXTIPE), and private
            consultants was effective in that consultants and AMEXTIPE
            alike contributed technical know-how and professionalism,
            while the municipalities provided intimate knowledge of the
            preferences of their constituencies. It allowed
            municipalities to leverage their otherwise weak capacities.
            2) Organizing and staffing the relevant vital services of
            municipalities and the local government directorate and
            building their capacities should have accompanied the
            introduction of the managmeent tools introduced byy the
            project--city performance contracts and audits--or even
            preceded it. 3) Enhancing the competitiveness of local
            construction and engineering firms requires sustained
            efforts by an appropriate mix of specialized institutions.
            Such responsibility is well beyond the scope of AMEXTIPE and
            is incongruent with the need to enforce stringent post
            qualification and other selection criteria.

repnme.cdata!:
Mauritania - Urban Infrastructure and Pilot
            Decentralization Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of the Urban
            Infrastructure and Pilot Decentralization Project are to: 1)
            create new temporary employment opportunities in rapidly
            growing urban and peri-urban areas; 2) help municipalities
            create or rehabilitate basic, urgent infrastructure assets;
            and 3) develop municipal capacity to manage these assets and
            help the Ministry of Interior, Posts, and Telecommunications
            (MOI) to play its tutorship role. The project will have two
            components: 1) a program of poverty-oriented,
            labor-intensive works sub-projects which will fall into the
            following categories: (a) economic infrastructure projects;
            (b) social infrastructure projects; (c) municipal
            income-generating projects; and (d) municipal management
            projects; and 2) capacity building (pilot decentralization)
            including: (a) infrastructure planning and urban space
            management; (b) management reform; (c) training of municipal
            staff and elected officials; (d) capacity strengthening of
            the Directorale of Local Government of MOI (DCL), the
            Decentralization Technical Coordination Committee (DTCC),
            and the Association of Mayors; and (e) reform of the legal
            and regulatory municipal framework.
